author: By Sam Corbin
title: Position of Intense Scrutiny
description: Freddie Cheng experiments with the initial phase of constructing.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Draper
title: Harris Cracked Down on Violent Offenders; Showed Leniency on Less Serious Crime
description: Her record as a prosecutor navigating both paths has left her open to criticism that she either betrayed liberal ideals or prioritized them over law and order.
content: From the moment that Kamala Harris took her place among 57 counterparts at the 2004 California District Attorneys Association annual conference, it was an open question how, if at all, the first Black, Asian American and female D.A. in the state’s history would fit in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft, Tricia Fulks Kelley and Ginny Whitehouse
title: ‘He Saved Many Lives’: Small Kentucky Community Mourns Slain Judge
description: The fatal shooting of the judge has rocked the town of Whitesburg. On Sunday, friends, family and community members gathered to remember the victim.
content: As a rural Kentucky town reeled from the fatal shooting of a judge, residents over the weekend mourned the victim whom many saw as a kind man who loved his community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Criticizing Oprah, Trump Falsely Claims He Appeared on Her Show’s Final Week
description: As he took aim at Oprah Winfrey’s interview of Vice President Kamala Harris, former President Donald J. Trump repeated a debunked claim that he was one of the show’s last guests.
content: When former President Donald J. Trump vented Saturday night about Oprah Winfrey’s recent interview with Vice President Kamala Harris, he resurrected a false claim that he had made before: that he appeared on the last week of Ms. Winfrey’s television show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Congress Unveils Short-Term Spending Deal
description: Speaker Mike Johnson dropped his demands for proof-of-citizenship voting requirements to strike a deal that includes more money for the Secret Service and funds the government through Dec. 20.
content: Congressional leaders from both parties unveiled a short-term agreement to fund the government on Sunday, after Speaker Mike Johnson abandoned demands for a longer-term deal that also included new proof-of-citizenship requirements for voter registration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Mercury Morris, Elusive Rusher on a Perfect Dolphins Team, Dies at 77
description: Part of a talented backfield triumvirate that also included Larry Csonka and Jim Kiick, he helped lead Miami to two Super Bowls and an undefeated season.
content: Mercury Morris, who gave speed and dexterity to the rushing attack of the Miami Dolphins in the early 1970s, helping to power the team to two Super Bowls victories and the only perfect season in the history of the National Football League, died on Saturday night. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario and Julia Jacobs
title: Drugs, Sex, Baby Oil: The ‘Freak-Offs’ at the Core of Sean Combs’s Troubles
description: Prosecutors say the sexual encounters in hotel rooms were coercive and abusive and are the heart of their sex trafficking case. The music mogul’s lawyers call them consensual.
content: A woman and a male prostitute gather for sex in a luxury hotel suite that, in the government’s telling, has been lit for filming and stocked with baby oil and drugs. Another man watches and sometimes captures the events on video. These sexual marathons, complete with a cleanup staff, sometimes went on for days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Spiers
title: These Two Rape Cases Are a Lot Closer to Home Than We Like to Admit
description: It’s easy to miss how much these cases have in common with everyday reality.
content: I was raped in college by an ostensibly nice guy who was not a stranger to me. I think that’s a banal statement of fact, but if that sentence makes you uncomfortable, I understand why. I describe it this way to point out how common my experience is. We regard rape in the public dialogue as an exceptional event, something that happens only in extraordinary situations. Pop culture — police procedurals in particular — have taught viewers to think of “real” rape as a thing that strangers do in dark alleys. But the reality is that most sexual assaults happen in situations where the victims know their attackers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Pamodi Waravita
title: Leftist Leader Elected President as Sri Lanka Rejects the Old Order
description: Anura Kumara Dissanayake’s strong showing reveals voter weariness with leadership that has led to a national economic crisis and crushing hardship for many people.
content: The Marxist candidate, Anura Kumara Dissanayake, was elected president of Sri Lanka on Sunday, riding a wave of popular anger at the established political order that ran the South Asian nation’s economy into the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: The Tumult that Transformed Racquet, the Tennis Magazine
description: The indie magazine Racquet aims to become a major player in the business of tennis — after a messy dispute between its two founders.
content: The U.S. Open looked like fun and games for Racquet magazine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: At a Remote Scottish Pub, a Pint Worth Hiking 20 Miles
description: The Old Forge on the rugged peninsula of Knoydart is a community-owned meeting point for locals and visitors — at least those willing to trek across the wilderness.
content: The simple pleasure of a hot pub meal and a cold pint can be found just down the street for most people in Britain. Then, there is The Old Forge: perhaps the most remote pub on the mainland, lying at the end of a multiday wilderness hike through craggy mountains and glistening lochs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Monday Briefing: Israel and Hezbollah Trade Threats
description: Plus, a Russian military officer’s story of desertion and escape.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said yesterday that Israel would take “whatever action is necessary” to diminish the threat posed by Hezbollah, while its deputy leader warned that the conflict was entering “a new stage.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: What Happened When an Ohio Megachurch Decided to Tackle Racism
description: In “Undivided,” the political scientist Hahrie Han follows members of a mostly white congregation that resolved to fight bias and promote racial justice.
content: Crossroads Church in Cincinnati has a style that stands out for its flash and irreverence even among its megachurch peers. At one Easter service, a production team shot confetti from the stage and presented a large cake with icing studded with communion wafers. “Jesus is alive!” they announced. “It’s a party!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: MAGA Wants Transgression, and This Is What Comes With It
description: Want more Mark Robinsons? Vote for Trump.
content: The North Carolina Republican Party is facing one of the most predictable crises in the history of party politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Will Warasila
title: A Changed Montana May Decide Control of the U.S. Senate
description: Republicans are trying to seize control of the U.S. Senate by ousting Jon Tester, the last Democrat holding statewide office in a state that not long ago had many of them.
content: For much of his life, Randy Gray knew his hometown in northern Montana, Great Falls, as a stronghold for Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah A. Topol
title: The Heavy Toll of Desertion From the Russian Army
description: Here is what we can learn about the Russian military and its soldiers from the story of ‘Ivan’ and ‘Anna’ in The New York Times Magazine.
content: Over the last year and a half, I reported from eight countries across four continents, including more than a year interviewing 18 deserters of the Russian military, for my story “The Deserter.” Together, their experiences gave me a vivid picture of the Russian war operation, its corruption, its chaos and its brutality. The deserters also gave me a window into how they found themselves fighting in the first place and why they then took the extreme measure to flee. My story focuses on one deserter named Ivan and his wife, Anna — pseudonyms we used for their protection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: First He Spoke for the Trees; Now He Speaks for the Sea
description: The wonders of the ocean and the terrors of A.I. meet in a Richard Powers’s new novel, which considers the future of an environmentally challenged Polynesian island.
content: The ecological novel has become a staple of contemporary fiction, and rightly so. When people aren’t really listening to the drumbeat of scientists, it’s essential that our best authors take up their sticks as well. Heck, bang a cymbal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone and Balarama Heller
title: Only Connect: Meredith Monk’s Antidote to What Divides Us
description: “Indra’s Net,” coming to the Park Avenue Armory, shows off the polymathic Monk’s artistry as she enters her 60th season as a performer and creator.
content: As the story goes, Indra, the king of the gods, takes a net and stretches it across the universe. At each joint is a jewel, unique and infinitely faceted, that reflects all the others in an endless web of interdependence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: U.N. Meets Amid a Backdrop of Growing Chaos and Violence
description: Beginning Tuesday, world leaders will discuss three wars, climate change, rising sea levels and proposals to expand representation on the Security Council.
content: When the United Nations General Assembly convenes on Tuesday, attention will focus on the major wars raging in Ukraine, Gaza and Sudan, amid a reckoning that neither the global body nor world powers have been able to end the violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: A French Fair as Workers’ Paradise, Feting Cuisine, Music and Communism
description: The Fête de l’Humanité, a blend of Burning Man, Woodstock and a political convention, attracts the masses with bands, lectures and food, but here K.F.C. is C.F.K.: Communist Fried Kitchen.
content: Christine Marlier was angry when President Emmanuel Macron called a snap election this summer. She’s even angrier now that he appointed a right-wing prime minister, despite the fact that a leftist bloc won the most seats in Parliament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Two Outer Banks Homes Collapse Into the Ocean in North Carolina
description: Nine homes in the area have been lost to the ocean in the past four years because of rising seas and storms that erode shorelines.
content: North Carolina park officials were warning visitors to avoid the beaches of the Outer Banks in Rodanthe this weekend after two houses collapsed into the ocean within hours of each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Venezuelan Gang’s Path to U.S. Stokes Fear, Crime and Border Politics
description: Tren de Aragua’s emergence in New York City and elsewhere has led law enforcement officials to strategize how to stem the gang’s growth.
content: At the country’s southern border, U.S. Border Patrol agents have been on the lookout for members of a notorious Venezuelan gang. In the nation’s heartland, police officers from Denver to Chicago have made dozens of arrests for alleged crimes linked to the group, from retail theft to murder and prostitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Congo Releases More Than 700 Inmates After a Deadly Stampede
description: At least 129 people died when inmates tried to escape from Makala Prison, where conditions are abysmal and overcrowding is a major problem.
content: More than 700 inmates were released from the largest prison in the Democratic Republic of Congo, the country’s authorities said on Saturday, as officials sought to ease overcrowding in a facility where at least 129 people died in an attempted jailbreak this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Pan-Seared Chicken With Harissa, Dates and Citrus
description: Sweet and sour with a peppery kick you can mellow out with dollops of yogurt.
content: Good morning. An hour before noon in the Hudson Valley, fog burning off the river in the sun, and it seemed entirely appropriate to tack east from the Catskill foothills toward Poughkeepsie and an early lunch from Rossi & Sons, where the muffuletta sub is beyond compare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Merelman
title: Interim N.Y.P.D. Commissioner Says Federal Agents Searched His Homes
description: Thomas G. Donlon, who took the interim role after Edward A. Caban resigned earlier this month, said the authorities had seized material unrelated to the Police Department.
content: New York City’s interim police commissioner said late Saturday that federal agents had searched his homes and seized material from them the day before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: A Surprise Season of Stranger Things
description: Standout shows from Bally and Bottega Veneta bring Milan Fashion Week to a close. Gucci, Versace and Moschino do some recycling.
content: And thus began the season of the weird. After decades in which clothes that telegraphed sex or stealth wealth dominated the Milanese runways, it’s the stranger things that seem the most on target now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert P. George
title: A Princeton Professor’s Advice to Young Conservatives
description: Grievance is not a good foundation for an identity.
content: As a professor who is known to dissent from progressive ideologies that are dominant at universities such as Princeton, where I’ve taught for nearly 40 years, I’m frequently asked by students for advice about how to navigate a campus they worry will be hostile to them. Some are pro-Israel, or politically and socially conservative, or religiously observant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sanjana Varghese and Malachy Browne
title: Videos Show Hezbollah Missile Hit Residential Area in Northern Israel
description: An overnight barrage included around 150 rockets, cruise missiles and drones, Israel’s military said. Air defenses intercepted most, but the town of Kiryat Bialik suffered a direct hit.
content: A missile fired by Hezbollah slammed into a residential neighborhood in the Israeli town of Kiryat Bialik on Sunday morning, setting cars and a building ablaze and blowing out the windows of nearby apartments, numerous videos verified by The New York Times show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabby Sobelman and Alissa J. Rubin
title: Northern Israel Braces for More Attacks From Hezbollah
description: Residents of Kiryat Bialik, a community near Haifa, were feeling vulnerable as the back-and-forth attacks escalated recently between Hezbollah and the Israeli military.
content: Even before Hezbollah launched more than 100 rockets, cruise missiles and drones toward northern Israel on Sunday, people who lived in the area feared they would be targeted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon, Euan Ward, Hwaida Saad and Ken Belson
title: Israel and Hezbollah Threaten to Hit Harder, Raising Fears of All-Out War
description: A leader of the Iranian-backed militia said its latest barrage was “just the beginning,” and an Israeli military official said, “Our strikes will intensify.”
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and a top Hezbollah leader vowed on Sunday to increase the intensity of their cross-border attacks, raising fears that the renewed conflict could escalate into all-out war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: The German Chancellor’s Party Ekes Out a Win Over the Far Right
description: The narrow win by Olaf Scholz’s party came in a state election, the third in a series that was seen as a reflection of the national mood and a snapshot of the government’s popularity.
content: The embattled center-left party of Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany scored a hard-fought and narrow victory over the far-right ethnonationalist party, Alternative für Deutschland, or AfD, in an election in an eastern state of the country, potentially energizing Mr. Scholz’s government in Berlin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: What to Watch For in a Key German State Election
description: The far right and far left are poised to make significant gains in state voting on Sunday, possibly affecting the stability of the national government in Berlin.
content: Voters are going to the polls on Sunday for state elections in Brandenburg, the eastern German state that surrounds Berlin like a doughnut, in a regional contest that could affect the stability of Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Bernstein
title: A Republican and a Democrat Sit Across From Each Other. There’s No Punchline.
description: One Small Step, an initiative that facilitates conversations between people with opposing views, is trying to tackle political polarization.
content: Alton Russell is a white, 85-year-old toilet paper salesman from Columbus, Ga., where for years he was the chair of the local Republican Party. Wane Hailes is a Black, 68-year-old newspaper owner from Columbus, where he formerly served as the president of the city’s chapter of the N.A.A.C.P.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Grabbing School Gear in Case of a Shooting
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 22, 2024.
content: “People say, ‘Oh, you’re just profiting off the carnage.’ And you know what I say? ‘Look, don’t blame me. I’m just the fire extinguisher manufacturer, OK?’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rajiv Shah
title: Want to End Poverty? Focus on One Thing.
description: Electrifying the world could produce the largest development gains since the 1990s.
content: In 2015, world leaders made an ambitious, unanimous commitment to help developing nations improve their prospects in health, employment, nutrition and access to affordable and clean energy by 2030. Every September, the United Nations and others assess how much progress has been made.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Heavy Rain in Japan Causes Deadly Flooding and Landslides
description: One person is dead and seven others are missing in Noto Peninsula, Japanese news media reported. The region is still recovering from a catastrophic earthquake.
content: Record rainfall in Japan’s Noto Peninsula caused deadly flooding and landslides in a region still recovering from a catastrophic earthquake earlier this year, the national broadcaster NHK reported on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Duehren
title: How Trump Could Upend Taxation in America
description: With slogans and in social-media posts, the former president has dribbled out ideas that, together, would fundamentally change how taxes are collected in the U.S.
content: At the start of the summer, when former President Donald J. Trump visited Republicans on Capitol Hill, he hinted at a vision for a vastly different tax system than what the United States has employed for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Some Palm Beach Ballots Misspelled Tim Walz’s Name as ‘Tom’
description: Officials in Palm Beach County, Fla., said that they had emailed 257 ballots to overseas voters before catching the error and correcting it.
content: When elections officials in Palm Beach County, Fla., emailed ballots last week to military and overseas voters, they failed to notice a typographical error: The name of Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, the Democratic nominee for vice president, was misspelled as “Tom Walz.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: The MAGA Movement Has Become a Problem for Trump
description: He can no longer run as if he is a man alone.
content: In 2024, the deep state that defeats Donald Trump might be his own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: The Politics of Motherhood Become a Campaign-Trail Cudgel
description: The presidential race has exposed a fault line in American political culture over the deeply personal decision to have children.
content: She is not humble. She has no stake in the future of the country. She and other childless women are looking down on Americans who have chosen to reproduce.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Told Myself Not to Judge a Book by Its Cover and Sat Down Next to Him’
description: Pleasantly surprised on the subway, an invisible helper appears and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: Widowed, 60, Seeking Affection
description: “The Golden Bachelorette” offers a glimpse at how dating changes after losing the love of your life. This is what it’s really like.
content: Four months after her husband of 30 years died in 2012, Kathryn Shephard Cowan went on a date to the symphony with a man who seemed perfectly nice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,192
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for September 23, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: The Surprising Reality of Political Violence in America
description: After two apparent assassination attempts against Donald J. Trump, it’s easy to think our politics are becoming more violent. The research is not so clear.
content: When Donald J. Trump was nearly assassinated in Pennsylvania in July, a Dartmouth political scientist named Sean Westwood happened to be in the middle of a research project asking Americans about political violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer, Reid J. Epstein and Michael Gold
title: Controversies Erupt as Trump and G.O.P. Make Critical Push to Voters
description: A Republican who reportedly called himself a “Black Nazi,” a false story about migrants eating cats and dogs, and a feud with Taylor Swift bring back a sense of chaos.
content: Even by the standards of a head-spinning presidential campaign, Donald J. Trump’s campaign over the past two weeks has been tumultuous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Hwaida Saad
title: In a Hezbollah-Dominated Area of Beirut, a Mix of Defiance and Unease
description: Many residents of Dahiya were grappling with uncertainty over what comes next.
content: The funeral drew thousands into the streets of the Hezbollah-dominated neighborhood in Beirut’s southern suburbs on Sunday afternoon, where many mourners shook their fists and proudly waved the armed group’s yellow flag. They had gathered to commemorate Ibrahim Aqeel and Mahmoud Hamad, two Hezbollah commanders killed in an Israeli airstrike last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Tongsun Park, Lobbyist Scarred by Koreagate Scandal, Dies at 89
description: An amiable Korean-born graduate of Georgetown University, he was imprisoned after a second scandal involving the U.N.
content: Tongsun Park, an urbane, amiable international lobbyist who stood at the center of two bribery scandals separated by nearly 30 years, and who was once a Gatsby-like figure in Washington whose flamboyant parties were attended by lawmakers, officials and the occasional Hollywood celebrity, died on Thursday in Seoul. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: In Michigan, Democrats Hope to Benefit From a Post-Biden Surge of Youth Energy
description: Democrats in the battleground state are counting on a sea change in the mood of young voters that could bolster their candidates in critical races that will determine who controls Congress.
content: When the Michigan State University College Democrats held their weekly meetings last spring at a sprawling residential hall on campus, organizers were lucky if they could get more than 30 students to show up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: Cat Missing in Yellowstone Returns Home to California After an 800-Mile Trek
description: The owners of Rayne Beau, the 2-year-old Siamese cat, have no idea how their cat made it back, but call his return a “miracle.”
content: When a cat dashed into the woods of Yellowstone National Park during a camping trip in June, his California owners, Benny and Susanne Anguiano, thought they’d never see him again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Kathryn Crosby, Actress and Bing Crosby’s Widow, Dies at 90
description: She was a Texas-born starlet when she married the beloved crooner, but put aside her career at his urging.
content: Kathryn Crosby, a Texas-born beauty queen and aspiring actress who put aside her movie career when she married Bing Crosby, the movie star and honey-voiced baritone, died on Friday at her home in Hillsborough, Calif. She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Charging the Parents of Mass Shooters
description: Readers discuss a guest essay criticizing charges against Colin Gray. Also: Jan. 6; turmoil in Central America; learning from dogs; blindness and courage.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Top Aides Resign From Embattled North Carolina Candidate’s Campaign
description: Most of the senior staff members on Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson’s campaign for North Carolina governor resigned on Sunday after reports that he had made a series of disturbing online comments.
content: Most of the senior staff members on Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson’s campaign for North Carolina governor resigned on Sunday, dealing a seismic blow to the embattled Republican who has faced widespread criticism after an explosive CNN report that he had made a series of disturbing comments on a pornographic website.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: College Investigating Report of a Student Scratching a Racial Slur on Another
description: A family says their son, a member of the swim team at Gettysburg College in Pennsylvania, was victimized when a teammate etched the slur across his chest with a box cutter.
content: School administrators at a small liberal arts college in Pennsylvania are investigating a report of a student scratching a racial slur onto another student’s chest at an on-campus residence this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 470
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Sept. 23, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: A Note From Irving Berlin, the ‘Nation’s Songwriter’
description: The lyricist and composer wrote thousands of compositions — and one stern letter to The New York Times.
content: Few songwriters and composers were as prolific as Irving Berlin, whose vast musical catalog includes well-known songs such as “Puttin’ on the Ritz,” “Cheek to Cheek” and “Anything You Can Do (I Can Do Better).” By some accounts, he wrote well over 1,200 songs during his career, including the scores for 18 films and 19 Broadway shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft and Yan Zhuang
title: 4 Killed in Shooting Near University of Alabama at Birmingham
description: Gunmen shot into a group of people in a popular entertainment district in what appeared to be a targeted attack, the police said. The authorities are still looking for the shooters.
content: Gunmen opened fire in a popular entertainment district in Birmingham, Ala., on Saturday night, killing four people and wounding at least 17 others in what appeared to be a targeted attack, the police said. The authorities said they were still looking for the shooters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: On the Trail, Trump and Vance Sharpen a Nativist, Anti-Immigrant Tone
description: From calling for mass deportations to spreading false claims about migrants’ eating pets, former President Donald J. Trump and his running mate, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, are taking a hard line.
content: As former President Donald J. Trump warned supporters on Saturday in Wilmington, N.C., that immigrants were “taking your jobs,” his running mate, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, campaigned about 500 miles north in Leesport, Pa., where he told his crowd that immigrants were taking their homes — and their children’s homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Moens
title: This Shark Lives 400 Years. Its DNA May Explain Why.
description: Scientists have mapped the genome of the Greenland shark, which could offer clues to the animal’s extreme longevity.
content: The Greenland shark is not exactly charismatic. Its hulking frame is covered by sandpaper skin. Its fins, stunted, sit awkwardly along its sides. And its eyes, perpetually cloudy, are often host to wormlike parasites that dangle as the shark slowly roams the depths of the North Atlantic and Arctic oceans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah A. Topol
title: An Escape from the Front Line in Ukraine
description: An excerpt from one of the most ambitious stories in The Times Magazine’s history.
content: Today, The New York Times Magazine published one of the most ambitious stories in its long history — an account of a Russian military officer’s desertion and escape. Sarah Topol spent over a year and a half investigating the Russian military and reporting in eight countries across four continents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Israel’s Military Closes Al Jazeera’s Office in the West Bank
description: The Israeli authorities have been putting pressure on the local operations of the network, saying its coverage threatens national security.
content: Israel’s military raided the office of the influential Arab broadcaster Al Jazeera in the Israeli-occupied West Bank on Sunday and ordered its closure for 45 days, the latest move in Israel’s effort to clamp down on the channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: More Than 700 Current and Former National Security Officials Back Harris
description: A letter signed by former secretaries of state and defense endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris and said former President Donald J. Trump poses a threat to the nation’s defense and its democratic system.
content: More than 700 current and former national security leaders, as well as former military officials, endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris in a letter released on Sunday, arguing that only she had the temperament and values needed to serve as commander in chief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Hawthorne
title: For the Children of Architects, Filmmaking as Therapy
description: Jim Venturi shines a light on his parents, the postmodern innovators Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown. How architects’ hidden lives are often revealed by kids.
content: Why have so many children of architects made films about their parents?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Schneier
title: Israel’s Pager Attacks Have Changed the World
description: Our supply chains are vulnerable, which means that we are vulnerable.
content: Israel’s brazen attacks on Hezbollah last week, in which hundreds of pagers and two-way radios exploded and killed at least 37 people, graphically illustrated a threat that cybersecurity experts have been warning about for years: Our international supply chains for computerized equipment leave us vulnerable. And we have no good means to defend ourselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: For Mideast Foes, Diplomacy Takes a Back Seat to Military Force
description: After years of failed deals and tit-for-tat violence, neither the Israelis nor the Palestinians believe their adversaries will ever negotiate in good faith.
content: The last, best chance for a peace plan between Israel and the Palestinian authorities came in 2008. Then-Prime Minister Ehud Olmert was prepared to give up territory in the West Bank, and allow some refugees to reclaim land. He was even willing to relinquish control of Jerusalem’s Old City to an international committee as part of recognizing Palestine as a sovereign state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Explosion at an Iranian Mine Kills Dozens, State Media Says
description: A methane leak set off the explosion, the country’s official media said, and a rescue effort was underway for those believed to be trapped in the mine.
content: A methane explosion at a coal mine in eastern Iran killed dozens of miners, and the death toll was expected to rise, Iranian state media said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 22, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 22, 2024.
content: An article on Sept. 1 about the charter city Próspera incorrectly described how council elections work there. While land ownership currently gives residents the right to vote for certain seats on Próspera’s council, residents do not need to own land in order to vote at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Kelsey Grammer Analyzes 40 Years of Frasier: ‘I Have Nothing to Regret’
description: The actor has been playing the snobby psychiatrist off and on since 1984 and has no plans to stop. He thinks the current “Frasier” reboot “could last another decade.”
content: Kelsey Grammer likes his raw meat cut very fine. On a recent afternoon, at the restaurant of a Midtown hotel, he requested that his steak tartare be put through the grinder twice. He wanted it, he said, like velvet. The tartare, topped with its quail egg, was presented roughly chopped. “I’ll deal with it,” Grammer said uncomplainingly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Kassie Bracken, Amy Marino, Audra Melton and Arthur Thompson
title: New Dynamics of Race Test Georgia’s Status as a Swing State
description: Many voters in the Atlanta suburbs were newly hopeful when Vice President Kamala Harris entered the race. But conservative values are still deeply rooted in the state.
content: Many voters in the Atlanta suburbs were newly hopeful when Vice President Kamala Harris entered the race. But conservative values are still deeply rooted in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKinnon de Kuyper
title: Hezbollah Retaliates Against Israel With Rocket Barrage
description: Hezbollah fired more than 100 rockets, drones and missiles into Israeli territory on Sunday morning. The attack came in response to strikes on militia members in Lebanon last week.
content: Hezbollah fired more than 100 rockets, drones and missiles into Israeli territory on Sunday morning. The attack came in response to strikes on militia members in Lebanon last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Associated Press and Reuters
title: Buildings in Suburban Beirut Badly Damaged by Israeli Strike
description: Crews in southern Lebanon sifted through rubble a day after an Israeli attack that targeted a meeting of Hezbollah commanders. The airstrike killed at least 37 people, Lebanon’s health ministry said.
content: Crews in southern Lebanon sifted through rubble a day after an Israeli attack that targeted a meeting of Hezbollah commanders. The airstrike killed at least 37 people, Lebanon’s health ministry said.
source.name: The New York Times
